chapter.title: C++ Support

note.para: The Gradle C++ support is in very early stages of development. Please be aware that the DSL and other configuration may change in later Gradle versions.

chapter.para: The C++ plugins add support for building software comprised of C++ source code, and managing the process of building “native” software in general. While many excellent build tools exist for this space of software development, Gradle brings the dependency management practices more traditionally found in the JVM development space to C++ developers.

chapter.para: Currently, there is no direct support for creating multiple variants of the same binary (e.g. 32 bit vs. 64 bit) and there is no direct support for cross platform source configuration (à la autoconf) at this time. Support for different compiler chains, managing multiple variants and cross platform source configuration will be added over time, making Gradle a fully capable build tool for C++ (and other “native” language) projects.

section.title: Usage
section.para: The build scripts DSLs, model elements and tasks used to manage C++ projects are added by the cpp plugin. However, it is typically more convenient to use either the cpp-lib or cpp-exe plugins that sit on top of the cpp plugin to preconfigure the project to build either a shared library or executable binary respectively.

The cpp-exe plugin configures the project to build a single executable (at $buildDir/binaries/$project.name) and the cpp-lib plugin configures the project to build a single shared library (at $buildDir/binaries/lib$project.name.so).

section.title: Source code locations
section.para: Both plugins configure the project to look for .cpp and .c source files in src/main/cpp and use the src/main/headers directory as a header include root. For a library, the header files in src/main/headers are considered the “public” or “exported” headers. Header files that should not be exported (but are used internally) should be placed inside the src/main/cpp directory (though be aware that such header files should always be referenced in a manner relative to the file including them).
The cpp plugin is also very flexible in where it looks for source and header files, aand you can configure the above conventions to look however you like.

section.title: Compiling
section.para: For both the cpp-lib and cpp-exe plugins, you can run gradle compileMain to compile and link the binary.

section.title: Compiling on UNIX
section.para: The UNIX C++ support is currently based on the g++ tool which must be installed and on the PATH for the Gradle process.

section.title: Compiling on Windows
section.para: The Windows C++ support can use either the MinGW g++ or the Microsoft Visual C++ cl tool, either of which must be installed and on the PATH for the Gradle process. Gradle searches first for Microsoft Visual C++, and then MinGW.

section.title: Working with shared libraries
section.para: The C++ plugin provides an installMain task, which creates a development install of the executable, along with the shared libraries it requires. This allows you to run the executable without needing to install the shared libraries in their final locations.

section.title: Dependencies
section.para: Dependencies for C++ projects are binary libraries that export header files. The header files are used during compilation, with the compiled binary dependency being used during the linking.

section.title: Publishing
section.para: The cpp-exe and cpp-lib plugins configure their respective output binaries to be publishable as part of the archives configuration. To publish, simply configure the uploadArchives task as per usual.

The cpp-exe plugin publishes a single artifact with extension “exe”. The cpp-lib plugin publishes two artifacts; one with classifier “headers” and extension “zip”, and one with classifier “so” and extension “so” (which is the format used when consuming dependencies).

note.para: Currently, there is no support for publishing the dependencies of artifacts in POM or Ivy files. Future versions will support this.
